questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of the animal cell?
questions.explanation: Animal cells have few, scattered small vacuoles. Presence of chromosomes is common to ALL cells.

questions.question: All living organisms
questions.explanation: All living organisms require food for energy and to build body structures. Plants transpire while animals do not. Not all living organisms can move or photosynthesize.

questions.question: The vacuole of a plant cell is
questions.explanation: The membrane-bound vacuole contains the cell sap; the membrane is called TONOPLAST.

questions.question: The part of the cell solely responsible for respiration is the
questions.explanation: Mitochondria serve as the site of energy release in aerobic respiration hence are called the 'powerhouse' of the cell.

questions.question: Which of these combinations is common to plant and animal cells?
options: Centriole, middle lamella, Golgi bodies, mitochondrion
Cytoplasm, sap vacuole, starch grains, leucoplasts
Nucleus, nucleolus, cellulose cell wall, endoplasmic reticulum
questions.explanation: Plasma membranes, chromosomes, mitochondria, and lysosomes are common to both plant and animal cells. Plant cells have cellulose cell walls and chloroplasts, while animal cells have centrioles.

questions.question: Where is energy produced in a cell?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are known as the 'powerhouses of the cell' because they produce energy in the form of ATP through cellular respiration.

questions.question: Which of the following cell constituents is NOT common to both plants and animals?
questions.explanation: Chloroplasts are found only in plant cells (and some algae) where they are responsible for photosynthesis. They are not present in animal cells.

questions.question: A group of similar cells performing the same function is
questions.explanation: A tissue is a collection of similar cells that work together to perform a specific function.

questions.question: The function of endoplasmic reticulum is
options: digestion and destruction of foreign bodies
questions.explanation: The rough ER (with ribosomes) is involved in protein synthesis, while the smooth ER helps with the transport of materials within the cell.

questions.question: The oxidative part of the respiration process takes place in the
questions.explanation: The oxidative processes, such as the Krebs cycle and the electron transport chain, occur in the mitochondria. Glycolysis (non-oxidative) occurs in the cytoplasm.

questions.question: The function of ribosomes in cells is
questions.explanation: Ribosomes are responsible for protein synthesis in cells.

questions.question: Which of the following structures is common to Euglena, white blood cell and Amoeba?
questions.explanation: All cells have cell boundary called surface membrane that serves as a boundary and controls the movement of substances in and out of the cell. Cell membrane = plasma membrane = plamalemma

questions.question: The structure labelled 5 is the
questions.explanation: Structure 5 is the Golgi body. Key: 1-Cell membrane, 2-RER, 3-Nucleolus, 4-Mitochondrion, 5-Golgi body, 6-Nuclear envelope.

questions.question: Which of the labelled parts of the cell contains RiboNucleic Acid?
questions.explanation: Structure 3 (Nucleolus) contains RNA. The nucleolus is involved in ribosome synthesis and contains RNA.

questions.question: Which structure is known as the powerhouse of the cell?
questions.explanation: Structure 4 (Mitochondria) are called the 'powerhouse of the cell' because they produce ATP, the cell's main energy currency.

questions.question: Which of the following structures is associated with aerobic respiration?
questions.explanation: Structure 4 (Mitochondria) are responsible for aerobic respiration, which involves the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain.

questions.question: The structure labelled 5 is used for
questions.explanation: Structure 5 (Ribosomes) are responsible for synthesizing proteins.

questions.question: The organelle involved in tissue respiration is the
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are the site of tissue respiration, where ATP is generated.

questions.question: A tissue can best be defined as
options: an aggregate of cells performing a similar function
an aggregate of similar cells performing the same function
a mixture of different cell types performing the same function
questions.explanation: A tissue is an aggregate of similar cells performing the same function.

questions.question: The membrane surrounding the vacuole in a plant cell is called the
questions.explanation: The tonoplast is the selectively permeable vacuolar membrane that surrounds the large central vacuole in plant cells, acting as a barrier between the vacuole's contents and the cell's cytoplasm. It regulates the transport of water, ions, and nutrients into and out of the vacuole, which is essential for maintaining cell turgor pressure, storing waste products and pigments, and protecting the cell from harmful compounds.

questions.question: Which of the following organelles are likely to be present in cells that are actively respiring and photosynthesizing?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are involved in respiration, and chloroplasts are involved in photosynthesis.

questions.question: The structure labelled I is the
questions.explanation: Endoplamic Reticulum (ER) with ribosomes attached is known as Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum (RER) .

questions.question: Protein is synthesized in the part labelled
questions.explanation: Structure III (Ribosomes) are responsible for protein synthesis.

questions.question: The nucleus is considered the control organelle of a cell because it
options: is bounded by the nuclear membrane
is located at the centre of the cell
questions.explanation: The nucleus contains the genetic material (DNA) that controls all cellular activities.

questions.question: The structure that is most commonly identified in all living cells under the light microscope is the
questions.explanation: The nucleus being the most easily stained structure as it contains chromatin material ('chromatin coloured body').Chromatin stains easily because it is composed of DNA, which has a negative charge, wrapped around positively charged proteins called histones. This basic nature of the protein component facilitates a strong electrostratic attraction to basic dyes, making chromatin highly visible under a microscope.

questions.question: Which of the following is an organ?
questions.explanation: Liver is an organ. Guard cell is a cell, xylem bundle is a tissue, blood is a tissue. Note: The maximum level of organization in hydra is tissue despite being organismal.

questions.question: In plant cells, the chloroplasts are located where?
questions.explanation: Cell organelles float in a sea of cytoplasm. Cytoplasm includes all cellular contents outside the nucleus. Note: Cell = Membrane + Protoplasm; Protoplasm = Living component of the cell; Protoplasm = Nucleus + Cytoplasm;  Cytoplasm = Cytogel + Cytosol

questions.question: Which of the following organisms does not exist as a single free living cell?
questions.explanation: Volvox exists as a colony of cells, not as a single free-living cell. Spirogyra exists as a filament. Cheek cell or hepatocyte exists as part of a whole organims.

questions.question: An Amoeba and an unlaid chicken egg are?
questions.explanation: Both are examples of single cells. Amoeba is a unicellular organism, and an unfertilized egg is a single cell.

questions.question: The structures found only in plant cells are?
questions.explanation: Cell wall and chloroplast are unique to plant cells. Other structures are found in both plant and animal cells.

questions.question: The endoplasmic reticulum is represented by the part labelled?
questions.explanation: Structure IV represents the endoplasmic reticulum

questions.question: The part labelled II is responsible for what?
questions.explanation: Structure II (Mitochondrion) is involved in respiration.

questions.question: The rods in the retina of the eye are examples of what?
questions.explanation: Rods and cones are specialized photoreceptor cells in the retina that detect light.

questions.question: The organelle common to both plant and animal cell is the
questions.explanation: The plasmalemma (cell membrane) is present in both plant and animal cells, while the others are specific to one type.All cells have cell boundary called surface membrane which is also called Plasma membrane or Plasmalemma.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have a higher concentration of mitochondria?
questions.explanation: Sperm cells require a lot of energy for movement, so they contain many mitochondria. They require enormous energy to travel through the female reproductive canal and the mitochondria supply this energy.

questions.question: The role of the Golgi complex in a eukaryotic cell is to
options: Conduct ions in and out of the cell
transport genetic material out of the cell
transport organic material in and out of the cell
questions.explanation: The Golgi complex processes, packages, and transports organic materials like proteins and lipids. Option B makes no sense because genetic materials only move from nucleus to cytoplasm.

questions.question: The organelle responsible for heredity is
questions.explanation: Structure III (Nucleus) contains DNA, which is the hereditary material in cells.

questions.question: The part labelled I is the
questions.explanation: Structure I is the plasmalemma (cell membrane).The cell organelles are enclosed by the plasma membrane including the cell nucleus. Unlike the animal cell lacking the cell wall, plant cells have a cell wall.

questions.question: A characteristic that can possibly be shared by both living and nonliving organisms is
questions.explanation: Non-living things (e.g., crystals) can increase in size, but they do not grow through metabolic processes like living organisms.Living things grow from within by incorporating more protoplasm through feeding. Non living things grow from outside e.g.a stalagmite or stalactite increases in size in a hot cave by adding new materials to the outside surface.

questions.question: The cell of an onion bulb can be differentiated from a cheek cell by the presence of
questions.explanation: Onion cells have a cell wall, while cheek cells do not, as onion cells are plant cells and cheek cells are animal cells.

questions.question: What is the level of organization of an onion bulb?
questions.explanation: An onion bulb is an organ in the plant, composed of different tissues working together for specific functions. Note that Onion is considered an underground shoot; however, the entire buld comprises root system + shoot system = organims. Furthermore, the shoot system = stem (organ) + leaf bases (organ)

questions.question: A characteristic exhibited by all living organisms is
options: the ability to move from one place to another
the ability to remove unwanted substances
questions.explanation: All living organisms excrete waste products as part of metabolism. Excretion prevents the build-up of metabolic wastes to toxic levels in the organism.

questions.question: In a cell, the genes are carried by
questions.explanation: Genes are found in the chromatin threads, which are located in the nucleus of the cell. Chromatin threads condense into chromosomes which bear genes.

questions.question: Which of the following characterizes a mature plant cell?
options: The nucleus is pushed to the centre of the cell
The cell wall is made up of cellulose
The nucleus is small and irregular in shape
The cytoplasm fills up the entire cell space
questions.explanation: Mature plant cells have a cellulose-based cell wall, which gives them structure and rigidity. As a plant cell grows older, deposition of cellulose intensifies and the single vacuole almost completely occupies the entire cell pushing the nucleus to one side of the cell.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of the nucleus of a cell?
options: It translates genetic information for the manufacture of proteins
it stores and carries hereditary information
it is a reservoir of energy for the cell
it controls the life processes of the cell
questions.explanation: The nucleus is responsible for storing genetic information and controlling cell activities, but it does not store energy; that is the role of mitochondria.

questions.question: The organelle responsible for heredity is labelled
questions.explanation: Structure II (Nucleus) contains the cell's genetic material (DNA), which carries hereditary information.

questions.question: The part labelled IV is the
questions.explanation: Structure IV is the endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.question: The organelles present in cells that are actively respiring and photosynthesizing are
questions.explanation: Mitochondria are involved in respiration, and chloroplasts are involved in photosynthesis, both processes are vital for energy production in cells.

questions.question: The lowest level of organization in living organisms is
questions.explanation: The cell is the basic unit of life and the lowest level of organization in living organisms.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most complex according to their cellular level of organization?
questions.explanation: The heart is an organ composed of various tissues working together, making it more complex than unicellular organisms like Euglena and Hydra, which are simpler in cellular organization. Hydra is a whole organism but its highest level of organization is tissue level

questions.question: Which of the following organisms is multicellular?
questions.explanation: Spirogyra is a multicellular organism, unlike Chlamydomonas, Amoeba, and Euglena, which are unicellular. Spirogyra is a chain of cells  (a filamentous algae).

questions.question: Spirogyra cell was placed in solution. After 1 minute the cell had been plasmolysed. The solution was
questions.explanation: Plasmolysis occurs when a cell loses water to a hypertonic solution, causing the cell membrane to pull away from the cell wall. A very strong sugar solution is hypertonic to the Spirogyra cell sap.

questions.question: The movement of molecules from a region of higher concentration to a region of lower concentration is
questions.explanation: Diffusion is the passive movement of molecules or particles from a region of higher concentration to one of lower concentration.

questions.question: A fresh kola nut weighing 1g was put into a salt solution. After 3 hours, the kola nut weighed 1.2g. This simple experiment demonstrates that
options: the salt solution is more concentrated than the cell sap
the cell sap is more concentrated than the salt solution
the salt solution has the same concentration as the cell sap
kola nut cells can multiply in water
questions.explanation: The kola nut lost water due to osmosis, indicating the salt solution was hypertonic (more concentrated) relative to the cell sap.

questions.question: The filaments of Spirogyra were put into equal amounts of sugar solutions X and Y. After 5 minutes, filaments from X solution had their cell contents rounded up while those of Y were unaffected. The experiment showed that
options: solution X was stronger than Y
solution Y is stronger than X
questions.explanation: The rounding of cell contents in solution X indicates plasmolysis, which occurs in a stronger/hypertonic solution.

questions.question: If an isolated living cell is left in distilled water for two hours, it is likely to
options: lose some water to the surroundings
lose all its water to the surroundings
questions.explanation: The cell will absorb water through osmosis from the hypotonic distilled water, causing it to swell and become more turgid.

questions.question: Which of the following will NOT allow osmosis to take place?
questions.explanation: Transparent polythene is impermeable to water and solutes, preventing osmosis, while the other materials are semi-permeable.

questions.question: When a Spirogyra cell is immersed in a salt solution more concentrated than its cell sap, it
questions.explanation: In a hypertonic solution, the Spirogyra cell loses water by osmosis, leading to shrinking and shriveling of the cell (plasmolysis).

questions.question: Osmosis can be defined as the movement of
options: molecules from high to low concentration
water from high to low concentration
water across a membrane from low to high concentration
water across a membrane from high to low concentration
questions.explanation: Osmosis is specifically the movement of water molecules through a semi-permeable membrane from a region of lower solute concentration to a region of higher solute concentration.

questions.question: Mineral salts can be absorbed into the roots by
questions.explanation: Mineral absorption involves diffusion (passive movement along concentration gradient) and active transport (energy-requiring movement against gradient).

questions.question: After 30 minutes, the level of sugar solution in the above Figure will
options: be the same in X and Y
questions.explanation: Water will move from Y (lower sugar concentration) to X (higher sugar concentration) through the semipermeable membrane by osmosis, causing the level in X to rise.

questions.question: The process by which water moves from Y to X through the semipermeable membrane is called
questions.explanation: Osmosis is the movement of water molecules through a semi-permeable membrane from a region of lower solute concentration to a region of higher solute concentration.

questions.question: The process by which a red blood cell placed in distilled water absorbs water until it bursts and releases its contents into the surroundings is known as
questions.explanation: Animal cells like RBCs lack cell walls. In a hypotonic solution (distilled water), water enters by osmosis causing the cell to swell and burst - this is haemolysis.

questions.question: Salts and water are absorbed in the roots and transported to the leaves by
questions.explanation: Water moves mainly by osmosis, and mineral salts dissolved in it are transported upward through the xylem tissues.

questions.question: When a marine fish was taken from the ocean and put in a tank of fresh water, it died after a short period because
options: its cells swelled and burst in hypotonic water
its cells shrank as their sap was hypertonic
it could not breathe in fresh water
questions.explanation: Marine fish are adapted to saltwater. Freshwater is hypotonic to their cells, causing water to enter by osmosis, leading to cell swelling and bursting.

questions.question: A marine protozoan is likely to have no contractile vacuole mainly because the cytoplasm is
questions.explanation: When the cytoplasm is isotonic to the environment, there's no net water movement, eliminating the need for a contractile vacuole to expel excess water.

questions.question: Which of the following can cause shrinkage of living cells?
questions.explanation: In a hypertonic solution, water leaves the cell by ex-osmosis, causing the cell to shrink.

questions.question: Euglena may be classified as a plant because it
questions.explanation: Euglena contains chloroplasts for photosynthesis, which is a plant-like characteristic. However, it also has animal-like features such as mobility, a pellicle instead of a cell wall, and a gullet for ingestion.

questions.question: Rhizopus (or Mucor) obtains its food from dead organic matter extracellularly. It is said to be
questions.explanation: Rhizopus is a saprophyte because it feeds on dead organic matter. Saprophytes, including fungi and some bacteria, are decomposers that play a key role in nutrient recycling.

questions.question: Which one of the following options is not true for Mucor or Rhizopus?
options: grows on moist dead organic matter
questions.explanation: Fungi like Mucor and Rhizopus have cell walls made of chitin, not cellulose. They are no longer classified as plants but belong to their own kingdom called the Fungi Kingdom .

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true of Paramecium?
options: the gullet is lined with cilia
questions.explanation: It is slipper-shaped with a blunt anterior end, a cilia-lined gullet, an anal pore for waste expulsion, and food vacuoles that move along a fixed path for digestion.

questions.question: One of the following statements is not true of viruses.
options: They can be seen with an ordinary light microscope
questions.explanation: Viruses are too small to be seen with an ordinary light microscope; they require an electron microscope for visualization.

questions.question: In Mucor or Rhizopus, carbohydrate is absorbed in the form of
questions.explanation: Fungi perform extracellular digestion, breaking down complex carbohydrates into glucose for absorption. However, they store glucose as glycogen.

questions.question: In Rhizopus, carbohydrate is stored in the form of
questions.explanation: Unlike plants that store starch, fungi store carbohydrates as glycogen, highlighting their distinct classification.

questions.question: In which of the following groups of animals are flagella and cilia found?
questions.explanation: Protozoa, such as Euglena (flagella) and Paramecium (cilia), use these structures for locomotion. Protists exhibit diverse movement mechanisms.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true of Mucor? It
questions.explanation: Mucor, like all fungi, lacks chlorophyll and is heterotrophic. It grows saprophytically, has hyphae, reproduces via spores in sporangia, and can undergo conjugation.

questions.question: Viruses are regarded as non-living because they
options: can neither reproduce asexually nor sexually
cannot survive in their respective environments
do not possess characteristics that can be transmitted from one generation to the next
questions.explanation: Viruses lack cellular machinery for metabolic processes like respiration and excretion. They only exhibit life-like properties when inside a host cell.

questions.question: Which of the following features of Euglena is found only in animals?
questions.explanation: The pellicle, a flexible protein layer providing support and flexibility, is an animal-like feature. Other options are plant-like (e.g., pyrenoid for starch storage) or common to both.

questions.question: The hypha of Rhizopus is said to be coenocytic because it
questions.explanation: Coenocytic hyphae lack septa (cross-walls), resulting in a continuous cytoplasmic mass with multiple nuclei, characteristic of some fungi.

questions.question: Spirogyra, Euglena and Chlamydomonas share many characteristics EXCEPT
questions.explanation: Spirogyra is non-motile, while Euglena and Chlamydomonas are motile (using flagella). All share photosynthetic nutrition, reproductive methods, and irritability.

questions.question: What is the function of trichocyst in Paramecium?
questions.explanation: Trichocysts are defensive organelles that discharge thread-like structures when the organism is threatened, providing protection.

questions.question: When a virus is placed in a non-living medium it
questions.explanation: Viruses can crystallize in non-living environments, behaving like non-living matter. They regain life-like properties only when infecting a host.

questions.question: A multinucleate body without internal cell boundaries is characteristic of
questions.explanation: Fungi often have coenocytic hyphae—multinucleate structures without septa—allowing continuous cytoplasm with multiple nuclei.

questions.question: Viruses are considered to be living organisms because they
options: move from one place to another
questions.explanation: Viruses contain genetic material (DNA or RNA) that can be transmitted to offspring, a key characteristic of life, despite lacking other metabolic functions.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics is common to Amoeba and Paramecium?
questions.explanation: Both Amoeba and Paramecium have contractile vacuoles for osmoregulation, expelling excess water to maintain internal balance.

questions.question: Which of the following are non-green plants?
questions.explanation: Fungi lack chlorophyll and cannot photosynthesize, making them non-green and heterotrophic. Others are photosynthetic.

questions.question: One of the features which adapts paramecium to its environment is the possession of
questions.explanation: Cilia enable Paramecium to swim efficiently, helping it escape predators, navigate toward food, and respond to environmental changes.

questions.question: The structure labelled X is used by the organism in the same way as man uses his
questions.explanation: Structure X (gullet) in Paramecium functions like the human oesophagus, transporting food into the cell for digestion.

questions.question: The structure labelled Y is the
questions.explanation: Structure Y is the macronucleus, which controls non-reproductive cell functions. Paramecium has both a macronucleus and a micronucleus.

questions.question: In which of the following organisms does a single cell perform all the functions of movement, nutrition, growth, excretion and photosynthesis?
questions.explanation: Euglena is a unicellular protist that photosynthesizes, moves via flagella, ingests food, grows, excretes waste, and reproduces independently.

questions.question: The spores of mucor are dispersed by
questions.explanation: Mucor produces lightweight spores that are easily carried by wind to new substrates, where they germinate and grow.

questions.question: Members of the phylum Protozoa use the contractile vacuole
questions.explanation: Contractile vacuoles osmoregulate by expelling excess water that enters the cell through osmosis, preventing bursting.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE of the process of conjugation in Paramecium?
questions.explanation: During conjugation, micronuclei undergo meiosis and exchange, followed by multiple divisions to produce genetically diverse offspring.

questions.question: The smallest living organisms which share the characteristics of both living and non-living matter are
questions.explanation: Viruses exhibit living properties (replication, genetic mutation) only within hosts, and non-living properties (crystallization) outside hosts.

questions.question: Which of the following does a virus have in common with animal cells?
questions.explanation: Viruses contain genetic material (DNA or RNA), similar to animal cells, but lack other cellular components like nuclei or cytoplasm.

questions.question: Virus differ from all forms of life because they
options: feed on waste products of other organisms
require other living cells to multiply
questions.explanation: Viruses are obligate parasites; they lack metabolic machinery and must hijack host cells to replicate, unlike independent living organisms.

questions.question: The prokaryotic cell type is characterized by a
options: complex cytoplasm in which different regions are poorly defined
localization of different regions of the cell into tissues
collection of organelles and macromolecular complexes
questions.explanation: Prokaryotes (e.g., bacteria) lack membrane-bound organelles and have a simplistic, poorly compartmentalized cytoplasm.

questions.question: The structure labelled I is formed as a result of the fusion of
questions.explanation: Structure I (zygospore) in fungi forms from the fusion of multiple nuclei during sexual reproduction (conjugation).

questions.question: The special name of the part labelled II is
questions.explanation: Structure II is the suspensor, a supportive hypha that holds the zygospore during fungal reproduction.

questions.question: The most recently evolved structure in animals is the
questions.explanation: Hair is a mammalian innovation, representing a recent evolutionary adaptation for insulation, sensation, and camouflage.

questions.question: The order in which organic evolution has progressed in plants is
options: Thallophyta, Schizophyta, Bryophyta, Pteridophyta and Spermatophyta
Schizophyta, Thallophyta, Bryophyta, Pteridophyta and Spermatophyta
Pteridophyta, Spermatophyta, Thallophyta, Schizophyta and Bryophyta
Bryophyta, Pteridophyta, Spermatophyta, Thallophyta and Schizophyta
questions.explanation: Plant evolution progressed from simple bacteria (Schizophyta) to algae (Thallophyta), then bryophytes, pteridophytes, and finally seed plants (Spermatophyta).

questions.question: Which of the following groups is the most advanced?
questions.explanation: Gymnosperms (e.g., conifers) are advanced vascular plants with seeds, surpassing non-vascular bryophytes and seedless pteridophytes in complexity.

questions.question: The animals that move by means of flagella include
questions.explanation: Chlamydomonas and Euglena are protists that use flagella for locomotion. Others use cilia (Paramecium) or pseudopodia (Amoeba).

questions.question: The umbrella-shaped fruiting body of a fully developed mushroom is the
questions.explanation: The pileus is the cap of the mushroom, which protects the gills and facilitates spore dispersal.

questions.question: The similarity among organisms belonging to the same group will be least within each
questions.explanation: Kingdoms (e.g., Animalia) encompass immense diversity, so members share fewer traits than those in lower taxa like species or family.

questions.question: The cell component that is present in prokaryotic cell is the
questions.explanation: Prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes for protein synthesis but lack membrane-bound organelles like chloroplasts, mitochondria, or a true nucleus.

questions.question: A plant-like feature in Euglena is the
questions.explanation: The pigment spot (stigma) in Euglena is light-sensitive, aiding in photosynthesis — this is a plant-like trait despite its animal-like features.

questions.question: The most common characteristics of the fungal hyphae is the possession of
options: cell-like compartments with one nucleus each
cell walls that are both rigid and chitinous
a multicellular mycelium in the substrate
questions.explanation: Fungal hyphae have rigid chitinous cell walls, providing structural support and protection, which is a defining fungal characteristic.

questions.question: The hyphal wall of fungi is rigid owing to the presence of
questions.explanation: Chitin, a tough polysaccharide, reinforces fungal cell walls, distinguishing them from plant cells (cellulose) or wood (lignin).

questions.question: The chromosomes of members of the kingdom Monera are within the
questions.explanation: Monerans (bacteria) are prokaryotic; their DNA floats freely in the cytoplasm without a nuclear envelope.

questions.question: In terms of the number of individuals, which of the following taxa is most inclusive?
questions.explanation: Class is a higher taxonomic rank encompassing multiple orders, families, and species, so it includes the most individuals.

questions.question: A blue-green alga is not a protophyte because
options: it is not a green plant
questions.explanation: Blue-green algae (cyanobacteria) are prokaryotic, lacking a true nucleus, which excludes them from protophytes (eukaryotic algae).

questions.question: Which of the following groups of cells is devoid of true nuclei
questions.explanation: Monerans (bacteria) are prokaryotic and lack membrane-bound nuclei. Viruses are non-cellular and not classified as cells.

questions.question: Which of the following is the lowest category of classification?
questions.explanation: Species is the most specific taxonomic level, representing a group of organisms that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.

questions.question: The fungi are a distinct group of eukaryotes mainly because they have
questions.explanation: Fungi lack chlorophyll, making them heterotrophic decomposers, which distinguishes them from photosynthetic eukaryotes like plants and algae.

questions.question: The organ which is sensitive to light in Euglena is
questions.explanation: The eyespot (stigma) detects light intensity, guiding Euglena toward optimal light conditions for photosynthesis.

questions.question: Which if the following is the simplest living organism?
questions.explanation: Viruses are the simplest biological entities, with minimal structure (DNA/RNA + protein coat) and no cellular organization, yet capable of replication in hosts.

questions.question: Fungi are referred to as heterotrophs because they
questions.explanation: Fungi cannot photosynthesize due to the absence of chlorophyll, so they obtain nutrients by absorbing organic matter from their environment.

4.class_of_TBP.name: Classification of Plantae: Thallophyta, Bryophyta, Pteridophyta

questions.question: The following events take place during conjugation in Spirogyra? 1. The protoplasm in each of the conjugating cells seperate from the cell wall to form a gamete; the gamete of one filament passes through the conjugation tube to meet the gamete of the other filament 2. The zygote soon become surrounded by a thick brown wall to become zygospore which bursts after a short rest and germinates to produce a new filament 3. The nuclei of the gametes fuse to form a zygote 4. The protuberances meet and where they touch the cell-wall disappears so that a conjugation tube joining the two cells is formed 5. Protuberances appear on the walls of cells of two filaments of Spirogyra lying side by side opposite one another. Now, what is the correct sequence in which the above events occur?
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: 5 (protuberances appear), 4 (conjugation tube forms), 1 (gametes separate and pass through the tube), 3 (nuclei fuse to form a zygote), and 2 (zygote forms a zygospore and germinates).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT true of Spirogyra?
options: It is a simple multicellular plant
During conjugation, its gametes, which are structurally and physiologically similar, fuse to form a zygote
It possesses a spiral chloroplast which enables the plant to photosynthesize
There are pyrenoids along the chloroplast
questions.explanation: The gametes are structurally similar, but one is physiologically male (the one that moves) and the other is functionally female.

questions.question: One common feature of the fungi, algae, mosses and ferns is that they:
questions.explanation: All these groups are seedless plants. Only spermatophytes (gymnosperms and angiosperms) produce seeds.

questions.question: In the provided diagram of Spirogyra, the structure labeled X is the:
questions.explanation: The outermost layer of the Spirogyra cell is the mucilage wall, which gives it a slimy feel.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the correct evolutionary sequence in plants?
questions.explanation: The correct evolutionary order from simplest to most complex is: Algae (Thallophyta), Mosses (Bryophyta), Ferns (Pteridophyta), Conifers (Gymnosperms), and Flowering plants (Angiosperms).

questions.question: Mosses, liverworts and ferns can be grouped together because they:
questions.explanation: All these plants reproduce via spores and lack seeds, which is a key shared characteristic.

questions.question: Spirogyra and Mucor can be grouped together as Thallophyta because:
options: their spores could be dispersed by wind
they are capable of living independent lives
their bodies are made up of thallus, and filaments alternatively
questions.explanation: Both Spirogyra and Mucor have simple plant bodies that are not differentiated into true roots, stems, and leaves, which is the defining feature of Thallophyta.

questions.question: Which of the following is INCORRECT? The prothallus of a fern:
options: is green because its cells contain chloroplasts
is attached to the ground by numerous rhizoids.
questions.explanation: The sporophyte, not the prothallus (gametophyte), is the dominant, visible plant in the fern life cycle.

questions.question: In Spirogyra, the Pyrenoid:
questions.explanation: Pyrenoids are proteinaceous bodies found within the chloroplasts of Spirogyra that are responsible for storing starch.

questions.question: Bryophytes are different from flowering plants because they:
questions.explanation: Bryophytes lack vascular tissues (xylem and phloem), a key difference from flowering plants, which are highly vascularized.

questions.question: In lower plants like mosses, the structure which performs the functions of roots of higher plants is called:
questions.explanation: Rhizoids are simple, root-like structures in mosses that provide anchorage but do not have a vascular system for absorption.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true of Spirogyra?
questions.explanation: Spirogyra consists of unbranched filaments, which is a characteristic feature of this genus.

questions.question: In a plant exhibiting alternation of generations, the diploid multicellular stage is known as:
questions.explanation: The sporophyte is the diploid (2n) phase of the plant life cycle that produces spores by meiosis.

questions.question: A characteristic that distinguishes bryophytes from flowering plants is the:
options: A. possession of true stems and leaves
D. ability to grow in moist habitats
questions.explanation: Bryophytes lack the vascular tissues (xylem and phloem) that are present in flowering plants.

questions.question: In most true ferns, sporangia are grouped into:
questions.explanation: A sorus (plural sori) is a cluster of sporangia, typically found on the underside of a fern frond.

questions.question: In the reproduction of mosses, water is essential because:
options: the male gametes must swim to fertilize the ovum
questions.explanation: Mosses have motile male gametes (spermatozoids) that require a film of water to swim to the female gametes (ova) for fertilization.

questions.question: The term 'Thallophyta' refers to:
questions.explanation: Thallophyta is a traditional division of the plant kingdom that includes simple, non-vascular organisms like algae and fungi.

questions.question: The prothallus of a fern is equivalent to the gametophyte generation of a moss because it:
questions.explanation: Both the prothallus (fern gametophyte) and the moss gametophyte are haploid structures that produce sexual organs (antheridia and archegonia).

questions.question: The algae, bryophytes and pteridophytes are similar in that they:
questions.explanation: All three groups have motile sperm that need a watery medium to reach the egg for fertilization.

questions.question: The spores of ferns are dispersed by:
questions.explanation: The annulus of the fern sporangium dries out, creating tension that causes it to snap open and forcefully eject the spores.

questions.question: In bryophytes, sex organs are produced in the:
questions.explanation: The haploid gametophyte generation of bryophytes produces the antheridia (male sex organs) and archegonia (female sex organs).

questions.question: Which of the following are differentiated into true roots, stems and leaves?
questions.explanation: Pteridophytes, which include ferns, are the first group of plants in evolutionary history to possess true roots, stems, and leaves due to the presence of a vascular system.

questions.question: The annulus of fern sporangia helps in:
questions.explanation: The annulus is a ring of cells on the sporangium that plays a crucial role in the explosive release and dispersal of spores.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly summarizes the life cycle of a fern plant?
questions.explanation: The life cycle correctly flows from the haploid prothallus (gametophyte) producing gametes (spermatozoid and egg cell), which fuse to form the diploid leafy plant (sporophyte) that produces spores.

questions.question: In which of these features do bryophytes differ from pteridophytes?
questions.explanation: Pteridophytes have a vascular system (xylem and phloem), while bryophytes do not.

questions.question: Which of the following organs or cell components are common to both the sporophyte and the gametophyte of a fern?
questions.explanation: Both the haploid gametophyte (prothallus) and the diploid sporophyte (leafy plant) stages of a fern are photosynthetic and therefore contain chloroplasts.

questions.question: Which is the correct order in an evolutionary sequence for the following plant groups?
questions.explanation: The evolutionary sequence progresses from simple, non-vascular life forms to more complex, vascular, and finally, seed-producing plants.

questions.question: One common characteristic of fungi, algae, mosses and ferns is that they:
questions.explanation: All these groups reproduce using spores, which are then dispersed to grow into new organisms.

questions.question: Based on the provided diagram of Spirogyra, protein-like bodies are borne on the part labeled:
questions.explanation: The pyrenoids (II) are proteinaceous bodies located on the chloroplast (V) and are involved in starch synthesis.

questions.question: Based on the provided diagram of Spirogyra, the sexual reproductive function is performed by the part labeled:
questions.explanation: The nucleus (III) contains the genetic material and is essential for sexual reproduction via conjugation.

questions.question: Which of the following perform similar functions?
questions.explanation: The indusium is a protective cover for the sorus, a cluster of sporangia, highlighting a similar protective function.

questions.question: In ferns, the sporophyte:
options: is haploid and dependent on the gametophyte
is diploid and independent of the gametophyte.
questions.explanation: The fern sporophyte is a diploid plant that is photosynthetically independent of the gametophyte once established.

questions.question: In which of the following organisms does each cell combine the function of nutrition, reproduction and growth?
questions.explanation: Spirogyra is a filamentous alga where each individual cell is capable of performing all essential life functions independently.

questions.question: Based on the diagram of a fern prothallus, the structures labelled II and III respectively are:
questions.explanation: On a fern prothallus, the male organs (antheridia) are typically located near the rhizoids (III), while the female organs (archegonia) are higher up (I).

questions.question: In ferns, the structure shown (prothallus) is equivalent to the:
questions.explanation: The prothallus of a fern is the haploid, gamete-producing generation, which is functionally equivalent to the gametophyte generation of a moss.

questions.question: Based on the diagram of a Spirogyra cell, the structures that are common to both plant and animal cells are labelled:
questions.explanation: Both plant and animal cells possess a nucleus (III) and a vacuole (II), although the vacuole in animal cells is typically much smaller.

questions.question: Based on the diagram of a Spirogyra cell, food is stored in the structure labelled:
questions.explanation: Food is stored in the pyrenoids (IV) in the form of starch, and it can also be found in the cytoplasm (III).

questions.question: One distinctive feature in the life history of liverworts is that they exhibit:
questions.explanation: Liverworts, as bryophytes, are characterized by a life cycle that alternates between a haploid gametophyte and a diploid sporophyte.

questions.question: The absence of special food and water-conducting systems restricts the body size in:
questions.explanation: Algae, liverworts, and mosses are non-vascular plants, meaning they lack specialized tissues for transport, which limits their size and requires them to live in moist environments.

questions.question: The dominant phase in the life cycle of a bryophyte is the:
questions.explanation: In bryophytes, the gametophyte is the larger, more conspicuous, and longer-living stage.

questions.question: A water medium is necessary for fertilization in:
questions.explanation: Like bryophytes, ferns have motile sperm that must swim through water to fertilize the egg.

questions.question: Alternation of asexual and sexual modes of reproduction is found in:
questions.explanation: Ferns exhibit alternation of generations, where a sexual haploid stage alternates with an asexual diploid stage.

questions.question: The dominant phase in the life cycle of a fern is the:
questions.explanation: The large, leafy plant that we typically recognize as a fern is the diploid sporophyte, which is the dominant phase.

questions.question: In bryophytes, sex organs are produced in the:
questions.explanation: The haploid gametophyte produces the sexual organs (antheridia and archegonia).

questions.question: Alternation of generation is a feature shown in:
questions.explanation: Mosses are a classic example of organisms that exhibit alternation of generations, alternating between a dominant gametophyte and a dependent sporophyte.

questions.question: The number shown as 8 refers to
questions.explanation: cuticle (made of cutin).

questions.question: The structure responsible for trapping the sun's energy during photosynthesis is
questions.explanation: Structure 3 is the palisade mesophyll layer, which is the primary site of photosynthesis due to its high concentration of chloroplasts and optimal position for light absorption.

questions.question: Which of these plays no role in photosynthesis?
questions.explanation: Structure 2 is the upper epidermis, which is a protective layer that lacks chloroplasts (with the exception of guard cells) and therefore does not perform photosynthesis.

questions.question: In the above diagram (Fig 1) the cell which controls the opening and closing of stomatal pore is
questions.explanation: The guard cells (E) control the opening and closing of stomatal pores. This function is regulated by changes in their turgidity, which is influenced by the movement of water.

questions.question: Root hairs have their origin from
questions.explanation: Root hairs are extensions of the epidermal cells of the root, specifically from the piliferous layer.

questions.question: One significant difference between roots and stem is that
options: branch roots originate in the pericycle while branch stems do not
stems are always above the ground while roots are always below the ground
stems are positively geotropic while roots are negatively geotropic
stems grows in both length and circumference whiles roots grow only in length
questions.explanation: Lateral roots (branch roots) originate from the pericycle, a layer of cells just inside the endodermis. Branch stems, however, develop from axillary buds on the stem.

questions.question: Which of the labeled tissues in the figure is responsible for the transport of mineral salts and water in a living plant?
questions.explanation: Structure 3 represents the xylem, which is responsible for transporting water and dissolved mineral salts from the roots to the rest of the plant.

questions.question: Which of the following tissues are made up of dead cells?
questions.explanation: The primary water-conducting cells of xylem, such as vessel elements and tracheids, are dead at maturity, which allows them to efficiently transport water and provide structural support.

questions.question: Root hairs are developed from the
questions.explanation: Root hairs are outgrowths of the epidermis (piliferous layer) of the root.

questions.question: Which of the following features can be used to identify Fig 1?
questions.explanation: The position of the xylem (7) in the transverse section of a dicot stem, which is arranged in a ring and extends towards the center, is a key identifying feature.

questions.question: The main function of 6 is to
options: conduct carbon dioxide to the other parts.
questions.explanation: Structure 6 is the cambium, a meristematic tissue responsible for producing new xylem (7) and phloem (5) cells, which enables secondary growth and stem thickening.

questions.question: The main function of 4 is to
questions.explanation: Structure 4 is the pericycle, the layer from which lateral roots originate.

questions.question: In a dicot leaf, guard cells differ from other epidermal cells because they
questions.explanation: Guard cells are the only epidermal cells that contain chloroplasts, allowing them to perform photosynthesis and regulate stomatal opening and closing.

questions.question: Herbs differ from shrubs because they
questions.explanation: Herbs are non-woody plants with soft stems, whereas shrubs and trees have woody stems.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of monocot plants?
questions.explanation: Monocotyledons generally do not undergo secondary thickening because they lack a vascular cambium, which is present in most dicotyledons.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT true of the piliferous layer of a root?
options: is the outermost layer of the cortex
is replaced by cork in old roots.
questions.explanation: The piliferous layer (epidermis) is the outermost layer of the root, not a part of the cortex. It is the layer from which root hairs emerge.

questions.question: Which of the following is seed bearing?
questions.explanation: Whistling pine is a type of conifer (gymnosperm), and conifers are seed-bearing plants.

questions.question: In an angiosperm leaf, the xylem is
options: in separate bundles from the phloem
questions.explanation: In a vascular bundle of an angiosperm leaf, the xylem is located on the adaxial (upper) side, while the phloem is on the abaxial (lower) side.

questions.question: Which of the following is common to a dicotyledonous stem and a monocotyledonous root?
questions.explanation: A central pith is a common feature in both a dicotyledonous stem and a monocotyledonous root. In a dicot root, the pith is often absent or very small, but in a monocot root, it is prominent and wide.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs are fully adapted to terrestrial life?
questions.explanation: Flowering plants (angiosperms) and conifers (gymnosperms) are fully adapted to terrestrial life because they do not require water for fertilization, unlike ferns, mosses, and algae.

questions.question: Which of the following has cones?
questions.explanation: Gymnosperms are a group of seed plants that produce cones to bear their seeds, a feature that distinguishes them from angiosperms (flowering plants).

questions.question: The stem differs from the root in having the xylem and phloem strands
questions.explanation: In stems, the xylem and phloem are located on the same radius, forming a vascular bundle. In contrast, in roots, the xylem and phloem strands are on alternate radii.

questions.question: The correct sequence of tissues in the anatomy of a young dicotyledonous stem from the inside to the outside is
options: pith, phloem, cambium, xylem, parenchyma, collenchyma and epidermis
xylem, phloem, cambium, cortex, endodermis, collenchyma and epidermis
pith, xylem, cambium, phloem, collenchyma, parenchyma and epidermis
phloem, xylem, cambium, cortex, endodermis, Collenchyma and epidermis
questions.explanation: The correct order of tissues from the center (pith) to the periphery (epidermis) in a young dicot stem is: pith, xylem, cambium, phloem, parenchyma (part of the cortex), collenchyma (part of the cortex), and epidermis.

questions.question: Secondary thickening is initiated in a dicotyledonous stem by the
questions.explanation: The vascular cambium is the meristematic tissue responsible for initiating secondary thickening, or an increase in the girth of the stem.

questions.question: Which of the following statements gives the BEST description of bark?
options: Cork-like tissues found only in stems
Brown tissues neverfound in primary growth
questions.explanation: The bark of a tree includes all tissues located outside the vascular cambium, which includes the secondary phloem and periderm (cork cambium and cork).

questions.question: In the transverse section of the leaf of maize vascular bundles are arranged in
questions.explanation: In a maize leaf, the vascular bundles are arranged in a circular pattern, with a layer of parenchyma or sclerenchyma sheath surrounding them.

questions.question: Double fertilization is a unique feature of
questions.explanation: Double fertilization is a complex process in which one sperm fertilizes the egg to form the embryo, and another sperm fertilizes the central cell to form the endosperm. This process is unique to angiosperms (flowering plants).

questions.question: The part labelled 3 is the
questions.explanation: Structure 3 is the dormant axillary (or lateral) bud, which is located in the axil of a leaf and can develop into a new branch.

questions.question: Which part of the twig produces auxins?
questions.explanation: Structure 1 is the terminal bud, which contains apical meristematic tissue. This tissue is a primary site of auxin production, a plant hormone that promotes apical growth.

questions.question: Angiosperms and gymnosperms belong to the plant group known as
questions.explanation: Angiosperms (flowering plants) and gymnosperms (cone-bearing plants) are both members of the division Spermatophyta, which is defined by the presence of seeds.

questions.question: To facilitate gaseous exchange, breathing roots have
questions.explanation: Breathing roots, or pneumatophores, have lenticels, which are pores that allow for the exchange of gases in waterlogged environments.

questions.question: A wide pith with a ring of conducting tissue is characteristic of the root of
questions.explanation: Maize is a monocot, and monocot roots are characterized by a large, well-developed central pith with vascular bundles arranged in a ring around it.

questions.question: The flow of air and water in or out of the mesophyll layer of a leaf is controlled by the
questions.explanation: Guard cells are specialized cells that surround the stomata and regulate their opening and closing, thereby controlling the flow of gases and water vapor.

questions.question: The major site of photosynthesis in the leaf is the
questions.explanation: The palisade parenchyma is the primary site of photosynthesis because its cells are densely packed with chloroplasts and are located in the upper part of the leaf, where they receive the most sunlight.

questions.question: Production of naked seeds is a distinctive feature of the group of plant called?
questions.explanation: Conifers are gymnosperms, a group of plants characterized by their 'naked seeds,' which are not enclosed within a fruit.

questions.question: Which of the labeled part allows for efficient absorption of water and mineral?
questions.explanation: Structure I represents the root hairs, which are responsible for increasing the surface area of the root to facilitate the absorption of water and minerals.

questions.question: Starch is usually stored in the part labelled
questions.explanation: Structure II is the cortex, and the innermost layer of the cortex is the endodermis, which is also known as the starch sheath because it stores starch.

questions.question: Secondary thickening in dicotyledonous stem is controlled by the
questions.explanation: The vascular cambium is a layer of meristematic cells that divides to produce secondary xylem and secondary phloem, resulting in the thickening of the stem.

questions.question: Stomata pores open when there is
options: an increase in the sugar content of guard cells
a decrease in the osmotic concentration of guard cells
a decrease in the sugar content of mesophyll cells
an increase in the sugar content of mesophyll cells.
questions.explanation: An increase in the sugar content of guard cells, which is a result of photosynthesis, increases their osmotic pressure. This causes water to enter the cells, making them turgid and causing the stomata to open.

questions.question: Which of the following structures is capable of producing more tissues in the stem of a herbaceous flowering plant?
questions.explanation: The cambium is a meristematic tissue that is responsible for producing new xylem and phloem cells, which allows for the increase in the diameter of the stem.

questions.question: Which of the following features are all associated with monocots?
options: Fibrous root system, branched network of veins and one seed leaf
Fibrous root system, two seed leaves and floral parts in threes
One seed leaf, petals in threes or groups of threes and parallel venation of leaves
One seed leaf, net-veined leaves and petals in three or multiples of three.
questions.explanation: Monocots are characterized by a fibrous root system, a single cotyledon (seed leaf), and parallel venation in their leaves. Their floral parts are typically in multiples of three.

questions.question: Peripheral arrangement of vascular tissues in dicots is a characteristic of the internal structure of the
questions.explanation: In a dicotyledonous stem, the vascular bundles are arranged in a ring or peripheral pattern around a central pith.

questions.question: Most monocots are easily recognized by their
questions.explanation: Most monocots, such as grasses, have long, narrow, and often sword-like leaves with parallel venation.

questions.question: The function of absorption is performed by the structure labelled.
questions.explanation: Structure II is the root hair, which is a specialized extension of an epidermal cell that increases the surface area for the absorption of water and minerals.

questions.question: The structure labelled I represents the
questions.explanation: Structure I is the pericycle, the layer that surrounds the vascular tissues and is responsible for the formation of lateral roots.

questions.question: In the Internal structure of plants, a wide pith in the centre is common to
questions.explanation: Both dicot stems and monocot roots have a prominent, wide central pith. In dicot roots, the pith is usually very small or absent.

questions.question: Angiosperms and gymnosperms belong to the class
questions.explanation: Spermatophyta is the taxonomic division that includes all seed-bearing plants, namely angiosperms and gymnosperms.

questions.question: The angle between the parts labeled ii and ii is the
questions.explanation: The angle formed between the upper side of a leaf and the stem is called the axil. The bud located in this region is the axillary bud.

questions.question: The part of the plant where photosynthesis is least likely to take place is
questions.explanation: Structure IV represents the root, which is typically located underground and lacks chloroplasts, making it the part of the plant where photosynthesis is least likely to occur.

questions.question: In the transverse section of a dicot stem, the region lying between the endodermis and the vascular bundle is the
questions.explanation: The pericycle is the layer of cells located just inside the endodermis and outside the vascular bundles.

questions.question: Monocot stems differ from dicot stems in that monocots have
questions.explanation: Monocot stems lack a vascular cambium, which is the meristematic tissue responsible for secondary growth and is present in dicot stems.

questions.question: The opening and dosing of the stoma are regulated by
questions.explanation: The movement of water into and out of the guard cells, which is a process of osmosis, regulates their turgidity and, consequently, the opening and closing of the stomata.

questions.question: In a dicotyledons stem, the zone between the epidermis and the pericycle is the
questions.explanation: The cortex is the region located between the epidermis and the pericycle.

questions.question: The structure that controls loss of water vapor during transpiration is labeled.
questions.explanation: Structure IV represents the guard cells that regulate the opening and closing of the stomata, which controls the rate of transpiration.

questions.question: The part labeled I is the
questions.explanation: Structure I is the spongy mesophyll, characterized by its irregular cells and large intercellular air spaces, which facilitate gas exchange.

questions.question: Which of the following is true if the transverse section of a dicot stem?
options: The xylem is more inferiorly located than the phloem.
The cambium lies between the cortex and the vascular bundles
The vascular bundles are randomly scattered within the cortex.
The epidermis is completely encircled by the cortex.
questions.explanation: In a dicot stem, the vascular bundles are arranged in a ring, with the xylem located towards the center of the stem (inferior) and the phloem towards the outside.

questions.question: Seed plants are divided into
questions.explanation: Seed plants, or spermatophytes, are divided into two main groups: angiosperms (flowering plants) and gymnosperms (cone-bearing plants).

questions.question: Plants that show secondary growth are usually found among the
questions.explanation: Secondary growth, which is the increase in girth of a plant, is a characteristic feature of dicotyledons due to the presence of a vascular cambium.

questions.question: Which of the following plant structures lacks a waterproof cuticle?
questions.explanation: The epidermis of a root lacks a cuticle to allow for the efficient absorption of water and minerals from the soil.

questions.question: Which of the following is involved in secondary thickening in plants?
options: Collenchyma and xylem & Vascular Cambium arth collenchyma cells.
questions.explanation: The vascular cambium produces secondary xylem and phloem, while the cork cambium produces the cork (bark), both of which contribute to the secondary thickening of the plant.

questions.question: Seed plants are the most dominant vegetation on land because of
questions.explanation: Seed plants have evolved efficient mechanisms for seed dispersal, which allows them to colonize new environments and is a major reason for their dominance on land.

questions.question: The part labeled l is the
questions.explanation: Structure I represents the root hairs, which are responsible for the absorption of water and minerals.

questions.question: The diagram is the transverse section of a
questions.questionImageDescription: The diagram shows a transverse section of a dicotyledonous root.
questions.explanation: The diagram shows a transverse section of a dicotyledonous root, which is identified by the xylem (ii) forming an 'X' shape in the center and obliterating the pith.

questions.question: Which one of the following animals is NEVER a secondary host of tapeworm?
questions.explanation: Man is a primary host for tapeworms, as the adult worm lives and reproduces in the human intestine. Pigs and cattle are common secondary hosts.

questions.question: The two types of human tapeworm can be distinguished by the presence or absence of
questions.explanation: The two common human tapeworms, Taenia solium and Taenia saginata, are distinguished by the presence or absence of hooks on their scolex (head). Taenia solium has hooks, while Taenia saginata does not.

questions.question: A tapeworm has no alimentary canal because
questions.explanation: A tapeworm is a parasite that lives in the small intestine of its host, where food has already been digested. It absorbs nutrients directly through its body surface, so it does not need a digestive system.

questions.question: Flatworms and roundworms are said to be invertebrates because
options: they can live inside the vertebrates
questions.explanation: The term 'invertebrate' refers to any animal that lacks a vertebral column or backbone.

questions.question: Which of these worms is beneficial to man?
questions.explanation: Earthworms are beneficial because they aerate the soil, improve its texture, and add humus, which makes the soil more fertile for agriculture.

questions.question: Exoskeleton is NOT Found in the
questions.explanation: Earthworms have a hydroskeleton, or fluid-filled body, that maintains their shape and assists in movement, unlike insects and other arthropods that have a chitinous exoskeleton.

questions.question: The parts used by tapeworm to fasten itself to the host Intestine are the
questions.explanation: Tapeworms use hooks and suckers on their scolex to attach firmly to the intestinal wall of their host.

questions.question: Which of these animals is radially symmetrical?
questions.explanation: Hydra exhibits radial symmetry, meaning its body can be divided into two identical halves by multiple planes that pass through its central axis. This is a primitive trait, while bilateral symmetry (found in the other options) is more evolutionarily advanced.

questions.question: Which of the following lacks chaetae, tentacles and antennae?
questions.explanation: Crabs lack chaetae (bristles for movement in annelids like earthworms), and they do not have the same type of tentacles as snails or the antennae of millipedes.

questions.question: A good example of a dłploblastkc organism is.
questions.explanation: A diploblastic organism, such as Hydra, has two primary germ layers: the ectoderm and the endoderm. In contrast, triploblastic animals (like earthworms and roundworms) have a third layer, the mesoderm, in between.

questions.question: The function of the ditellum in the earthworm is to
questions.explanation: The clitellum is a glandular structure in the earthworm that secretes a mucus-like substance that forms a cocoon for storing the eggs.

questions.question: In tapeworm, the two structures that run through the length of the body are the
options: nerve cord and the excretory duct
sperm duct and the nerve cord
genital pore and the excretory duct
sperm duct and the genital pore.
questions.explanation: A tapeworm has a simple nervous system with nerve cords and a pair of excretory ducts that extend along the entire length of its body.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of snails?
options: Soft unsegmented body in a mantle
questions.explanation: Snails have a calcareous (calcium carbonate) exoskeleton, or shell, not a chitinous one like insects and crustaceans.

questions.question: The Following organisms are hermaphrodites except
questions.explanation: Schistosoma (blood fluke) has separate sexes, while snails, tapeworms (Taenia), and earthworms are hermaphrodites, meaning they have both male and female reproductive organs.

questions.question: Parasitic Forms are NOT found among
questions.explanation: While some molluscs can be commensals or have complex relationships with other organisms, they are not typically known for being parasitic. Platyhelminthes (tapeworms), nematodes (roundworms), and annelids (leeches) all have well-known parasitic members.

questions.question: Which of the following sets of organisms represents the correct trend from simple to complex structural organization? 1. Mollusca 2. Platyhelminthes 3. Nematoda 4. Protozoa
questions.explanation: The correct evolutionary sequence from simple to complex is: Protozoa (4), Platyhelminthes (2), Nematoda (3), and Mollusca (1).

questions.question: At which stage in this cycle can man be infected?
questions.explanation: Man becomes infected with tapeworm by eating undercooked meat (pork or beef) containing the larval stage, or bladderworms (stage 4).

questions.question: Which stage is found in the muscle of an infected pig?
questions.explanation: The bladderworm, or cysticercus, is the larval stage of the tapeworm that encysts in the muscles of the secondary host, such as a pig (stage 4).

questions.question: A characteristic of the phylum coelenterata is that
options: A. most of them are marine
B. they possess a gut with a single opening
C. they possess numerous pores on their body
questions.explanation: Coelenterates (also known as Cnidarians) have a gastrovascular cavity, or gut, with only one opening that functions as both the mouth and the anus.

questions.question: Which of the following phyla has members with both internal and external segmentation?
questions.explanation: Annelids (segmented worms like the earthworm) exhibit both internal and external segmentation, a feature known as metamerism.

questions.question: The body of a snail is divided into head
questions.explanation: The body of a snail is divided into three main parts: the head (which contains the sense organs), the muscular foot (used for locomotion), and the visceral mass (which contains the internal organs and is covered by the shell).

questions.question: Hydra moves undigested food by
options: egesting it through the body surface.
questions.explanation: Since Hydra has only one opening for its gut, it egests undigested food and waste material back out through its mouth.

questions.question: Which of the following groups of invertebrates reproduces by budding.
questions.explanation: Asexual reproduction in Hydra, a member of the phylum Coelenterata, occurs through budding. A small outgrowth forms on the body, develops into a new individual, and then detaches.

questions.question: In a tapeworm, the sucker on the scolex are used for
options: sucking the blood of the host
questions.explanation: The suckers on the scolex (head) of a tapeworm are used for attachment and to hold fast to the host's intestinal wall.

questions.question: Sting cells are normally found in
questions.explanation: Hydra and other members of the phylum Coelenterata possess specialized stinging cells called cnidoblasts (or nematocysts) on their tentacles, which are used for defense and to capture prey.

questions.question: In the earthworm, the cocoon is secreted by the
questions.explanation: The clitellum is a glandular swelling on the earthworm that secretes the cocoon in which the eggs are deposited.

questions.question: The respiratory organ in the land snail is the?
questions.explanation: The mantle cavity of the land snail functions as a primitive lung for respiration.

questions.question: A major difference between platyhelminthes and coelenterates is that platyhelminthes
questions.explanation: Platyhelminthes (flatworms) are triploblastic, meaning they have a mesoderm layer between the ectoderm and endoderm. Coelenterates are diploblastic and lack this layer.

questions.question: The essential structural difference between Hydra and tapeworm is that while Hydra is
options: has a mouth, tapeworm feeds by suckers
questions.explanation: Hydra is a diploblastic organism with two germ layers, while a tapeworm is a triploblastic organism with three germ layers, including a mesoderm.

questions.question: The soll swallowed by the earthworm to form the worm cast is ground up in the
questions.explanation: The gizzard of the earthworm is a muscular organ that grinds up the soil and any ingested organic matter, preparing it for digestion.

questions.question: The cnidoblast cells found in Hydra are used for
questions.explanation: Cnidoblasts, or stinging cells, are used by Hydra and other coelenterates to stun or kill prey and to defend against predators.

questions.question: Annelids differ from nematodes in that they
questions.explanation: Annelids are characterized by metameric segmentation, which is the division of their body into a series of repeating segments. Nematodes do not have this feature.

questions.question: In snails, the hard calcareous shells are secreted by the
questions.explanation: The mantle is a soft, fleshy tissue that secretes the calcium carbonate necessary to form the snail's hard, protective shell.

questions.question: The habitat of the cysticercus of taenia solium is
questions.explanation: The cysticercus, or bladder worm, is the larval stage of Taenia solium that is found encysted in the muscles of pigs.

questions.question: The division of a body into two equal halves along a longitudinal plane is called
questions.explanation: Bilateral symmetry is a body plan where a single longitudinal plane can divide the body into two identical, mirror-image halves.

questions.question: Coelom is absent in the dass of animals termed
questions.explanation: A coelom is a true body cavity that is fully lined with mesoderm. Coelenterates are diploblastic and do not possess a mesoderm, and therefore they lack a coelom.

questions.question: An example of a radially symmetrical organism is
questions.explanation: Hydra is a classic example of a radially symmetrical organism, a body plan in which parts are arranged around a central axis.

questions.question: The leech and the earthworm belong to the
questions.explanation: Leeches and earthworms are both segmented worms that belong to the phylum Annelida.

questions.question: One primitive feature of the coelenterates is the possession of
questions.explanation: Radial symmetry is a primitive body plan that evolved before bilateral symmetry.

questions.question: Which of the organisms is characterized by the possession of a chitinous exoskeleton?
questions.explanation: Organism I is an insect (a type of arthropod), and all arthropods are characterized by a chitinous exoskeleton.

questions.question: The type of reproduction illustrated in IV is
questions.explanation: Organism IV is Hydra, which reproduces asexually through budding. A small bud grows on the parent's body and eventually detaches to become a new individual.

questions.question: Radial symmetry is a feature common to the
questions.explanation: Radial symmetry is a key feature of the phylum Coelenterata, which includes Hydra, jellyfish, and sea anemones.

questions.question: The structure labeled X is for
questions.explanation: Structure X is the scolex (head) of a tapeworm, which is equipped with hooks and suckers for attachment to the host's intestinal wall.

questions.question: The habitat of the organism is
options: under leaf litter of forest floor
questions.explanation: Tapeworms are endoparasites that live in the small intestine of large vertebrates, where they absorb already-digested nutrients.

questions.question: Which of the following Is most advanced in the evolutionary trend of animals?
questions.explanation: The cockroach is a member of the phylum Arthropoda, which is considered the most evolutionarily advanced among the options provided due to its segmented body, jointed appendages, and specialized organ systems.

questions.question: An animal body that can be cut along Its axis in any plane to give two Identical parts is said to be,
questions.explanation: This describes radial symmetry, which is a characteristic of coelenterates and echinoderms.

questions.question: Tanania solium can be found in
questions.explanation: Taenia solium, or the pork tapeworm, uses the pig as its secondary host, where the larval stage (cysticercus) develops in the muscle.

questions.question: The structure labelled II is the
questions.explanation: Structure II is the clitellum, a swollen, glandular band on the earthworm that is involved in reproduction by secreting the cocoon.

questions.question: The organisms Is found in soils rich in
questions.explanation: Earthworms are commonly found in soils rich in humus, which they feed on and help to decompose, thereby improving soil fertility.

questions.question: The organ for attachment to the lining of the host's intestine are labeled
questions.explanation: Structures II (hooks) and III (suckers) are located on the scolex and are used for attachment to the host's intestinal wall.

questions.question: The young proglottids of organisms is represented by
questions.explanation: Young proglottids are produced in the neck region (IV) of the tapeworm and are the segments closest to the scolex.
